document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Commentary
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics & NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Commentary

Link to Contents

 

This commentary, prepared by Mr Andrew Roberts, is based upon the results of a literature search and is founded on the systematic review’s abstract or other summary, and the inclusion of a study in this update does not imply endorsement. The specialist collections do not accept responsibility for the content or quality of included studies.

 

Behavioural Therapy

The role of psychological factors on outcome in acute and chronic low back pain is widely accepted. Treatments aimed at altering the patient's psychological reaction to their condition have the potential to alter the clinical course. A Cochrane review found that pain relief was provided by operant and behavioural therapy in the short term [1]. Interestingly, the review concluded that psychological treatments did not improve the efficacy of a chronic back pain treatment program.



Drugs

Kanis et al report on the efficacy of Raloxifene on vertebral fracture risk in a previously reported RCT according to the patient's predicted risk of fracture at the outset of the study [2]. Whilst Raloxifene has oestrogenic effects on bone, it has anti-oestrogenic effects on the breast and uterus. Raloxifene appears to reduce morphometric vertebral fracture to a greater extent in younger post menopausal women than older women. In a review of pharmacological treatment for chronic low back pain, Kuijpers et al usefully looked at the risk of bias (RoB) in the included studies. Short term benefit was found for NSAIDs and opioids with no benefit from antidepressants. NSAIDs and opiates were both found to be associated with an appreciable risk of side effects [3]. Papaleontiou et al documented a 30% incidence of constipation, 28% incidence of nausea and a 22% incidence of dizziness in older patients treated for low back pain with opiates, leading to a quarter of patients discontinuing treatment [4].

In a review of injection treatment and denervation procedures for low back pain, Henschke found low to very low quality evidence to support these treatments [5]. Epidural injection for lumbar radiculopathy appears to be more effective when higher volumes are used [6].

 

Therapy

Choi examined the role of exercise as a primary and post treatment intervention with regard to the risk of recurrent low back pain [7]. There was moderate evidence to support an exercise program after other treatment but as a primary treatment modality, the evidence was confused. Heterogeneity of exercise types may well contribute to the confused picture. Only limited evidence was found to support the notion that targeting exercise and manual therapy more selectively would result in better outcomes [8, 9, 10, 11]. There is a lack of an evidence base to support differing strategies to enhance patient compliance with exercise programmes [12]. In acute low back pain there is some support for manipulation treatment in the relief of pain and improvement of function [13].

Manual therapy for neck pain in adults appears to offer benefits compared with natural history, but the studies providing the evidence base are more often than not open to the risk of bias and of mediocre quality, according to D'Sylva et al [14].

Moderate evidence supports advice that staying active leads to a greater improvement than resting in bed [15]. On average we spend a third of our lives in bed - hopefully asleep, but a review of the effect of chronic low back pain on the duration and quality of sleep experienced by sufferers demonstrated a consistently detrimental effect on all aspects of sleep [16]. The effect of exercise on work disability was examined by Oesch et al, finding a significant positive benefit in the long but not short and medium term [17]. In a Cochrane review, Schaafsma et al found some evidence that a physical conditioning programme could reduce recurrent back disability in patients with subacute and chronic low back pain [18]. In a review of physiotherapist provided operant conditioning (POC), Bunzli et al showed a significantly positive effect in 8 of the 15 studies included [19]. The best way to integrate POC into other components of the physical therapy package needs to be explored.

TENS is examined in a review article from the American Academy of Neurology with a conclusion that it should not be recommended for the management of chronic low back pain [20].

When deciding on investigation and treatment, practitioners who are not necessarily experts form the audience for guidelines. Bouwmeester et al have revisited the quality of guidelines noting an improvement since 2004 [21]. Their paper includes a useful checklist for any guideline author. Specific areas for improvement identified were the applicability (barriers to introduction, costs and audit criteria) and editorial independence (from pharmaceutical involvement). Back pain in childhood may be related to a spondylolisthesis (grade I) or spondylolysis. In a review of non-operative treatment, Klein et al found that 83% of patients are improved at 12 months after presentation irrespective of whether they are braced or not [22].

 

Diagnosis

Pain

Facet joint nerve blocks and provocative discography have good to moderate supporting evidence, whilst diagnostic sacroiliac joint blocks have fair to poor evidential support. Cervical discography may have a role in the assessment of neck pain, but the quality of evidence is poor and a clear view of the risks is lacking [23]. The role of the sacroiliac joint as a symptom source is a subject of debate, with medically qualified clinicians viewing it as an uncommon problem. Clinical tests for SI joint pathology are reviewed by Szadek et al, but without diagnostic local anaesthetic blocks acting as a gold standard, uncertainty persists concerning the meaning of a positive test [24]. Clinical examination as a diagnostic technique to identify lumbar disc herniation causing nerve root compression was subjected to a Cochrane review, finding that signs such as a positive Lasegue test have high sensitivity but low specificity [25]. Combining tests was thought to be potentially useful in improving specificity but there was little evidence on this in the literature. As a final thought on diagnosis, French et al performed a Cochrane review examining educational programs aimed at improving clinician's adherence to imaging protocols in musculoskeletal conditions. The difficulty of changing clinical behaviour was again demonstrated [26].

Trauma

When dealing with an unconscious patient with a possible cervical spine injury, CT scans have a false negative rate. Schoenfeld et al reviewed the literature examining MRI scanning in addition to CT, concluding that in 1:8 cases an MRI will reveal an otherwise undiagnosed injury [27]. Only a prospective study of sufficient power would identify the true value of MRIs in addition to CT as well as the risk involved in obtaining the scans for trauma cases.

 

Aetiology and Epidemiology

A Canadian collaboration has published extensively on the literature concerned with the causal factors related to low back pain. They point out that many of the studies may note associations between environmental factors and back pain, but frequently the precepts required for a robust assertion of causality are not present [28]. To summarise:

  • Occupational lifting: Moderate causality for certain types of lifting [29]
  • Occupational bending and twisting: No causal link [30]
  • Occupational carrying: No causal link [31]
  • Occupational sitting: No causal link [32]
  • Occupational standing or walking: No causal link [33]
  • Occupational pushing and pulling: No causal link [34]
  • Occupational assisting patients with walking: Possible link [35]
  • Occupational manual handling: No causal link [35]

Prolonged computer use is often cited as a factor in postural pain however, the evidence to support this association for "neck tension syndrome" is limited, as judged in a review by Waersted et al [36]. In what is described as a meta-epidemiological review, Heitz et al examined predictive factors for return to work in subacute and chronic low back pain [37]. They categorise predictive factors as biomedical or psychosocial as well as potentially modifiable or immutable. Psychosocial modifiable factors appear to be more prevalent in the subacute patient as opposed to the chronic sufferer. Lakke also highlighted the psychosocial predictors of persisting symptoms [38].

Shiri et al found that smokers have an increased chance of low back pain particularly if they are adolescents [39]. Excessive weight also acts as a risk factor for seeking help with back pain [40].

 

Disability Measures

Two commonly used back pain disability questionnaires were compared [41]. For higher levels of disability and chronic problems, the Oswestry Disability Index is most appropriate whilst the Roland and Morris disability questionnaire is more sensitive to the levels of pain commonly encountered in the community. Choosing the correct measurement instrument requires care [42].

 

Bibliography

[1] Henschke N, Ostelo RW, van Tulder MW, Vlaeyen JW, Morley S, Assendelft WJ, et al. Behavioural treatment for chronic low-back pain. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2010;7:CD002014.   [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF] 

[2] Kanis JA, Johansson H, Oden A, McCloskey EV. A meta-analysis of the efficacy of raloxifene on all clinical and vertebral fractures and its dependency on FRAX. Bone. 2010 Oct;47(4):729-735.    [ Link to PubMed ]

[3] Kuijpers T, van Middelkoop M, Rubinstein SM, Ostelo R, Verhagen A, Koes BW, et al. A systematic review on the effectiveness of pharmacological interventions for chronic non-specific low-back pain. Eur Spine J. 2010 Jul.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

[4] Papaleontiou M, Henderson CR, Turner BJ, Moore AA, Olkhovskaya Y, Amanfo L, et al. Outcomes associated with opioid use in the treatment of chronic noncancer pain in older adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis. J Am Geriatr Soc. 2010 Jul;58(7):1353-69.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[5] Henschke N, Kuijpers T, Rubinstein SM, van Middelkoop M, Ostelo R, Verhagen A, et al. Injection therapy and denervation procedures for chronic low-back pain: A systematic review. Eur Spine J. 2010 Sep;19(9):1425-1449.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Commentary on Ankylosing Spondylitis
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics & NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,MAJOR INFLAMMATORY,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,SERONEGATIVE SPONDYLARTHROPATHIES,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Commentary on Ankylosing Spondylitis

Link to Contents

 

This commentary, prepared by Dr Robin Butler, is based upon the results of a literature search and is founded on the systematic review’s abstract or other summary, and the inclusion of a study in this update does not imply endorsement. The specialist collections do not accept responsibility for the content or quality of included studies.

This Annual Evidence Update includes the results of a search for new national guidance and systematic reviews published in the past year. Although many studies on different clinical and laboratory aspects of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) have been published during this period there have been relatively few studies which fall into these categories.

Drug treatment
A systematic literature review of randomized controlled studies of NSAID and TNF-inhibitors in AS concluded that both classes of agent had a large or medium treatment effect on pain, physical function and patient’s global assessment although not on mobility. This study found only a trend in favour of TNF-inhibitors but as the authors point out such drugs are given on top of NSAIDs in refractory patients. Only TNF-inhibitors reduced acute phase reactants [1].

An evaluation of the cost effectiveness of etoricoxib (90 mg/day) relative to celecoxib (200 or 400 mg/day), naproxen (1000 mg/day) and diclofenac (150 mg/day) in the initial treatment of ankylosing spondylitis concluded that from the UK NHS perspective, etoricoxib is the most cost-effective initial NSAID treatment for AS patients [2].

It is well-recognised that the use of TNF-inhibitors is associated with a small but significant  increase in the risk of infection in people with rheumatoid arthritis. A systematic review evaluated the risk of infection in people with AS and concluded that the absolute risk of serious infections in patients with AS not exposed to TNF-inhibitors is low and although higher in patients receiving TNF-inhibitors the difference was not significant, possibly through lack of power of the study. As the authors point out further longitudinal studies will be required to evaluate the magnitude of any increased risk [3]. 

Disease susceptibility
It is probable that genetic factors other than HLA-B27 contribute to susceptibility to AS. The efficacy of TNF-inhibitors in AS raised the possibility that TNF-alpha promoter polymorphisms might be associated with susceptibility to AS. However two meta-analyses concluded that there was no association between TNF-alpha promoter polymorphisms and AS [4,5].

 

References

[1] Escalas C, Trijau S, Dougados M. Evaluation of the treatment effect of NSAIDs/TNF blockers according to different domains in ankylosing spondylitis: Results of a meta-analysis. Rheumatology. 2010 Jul;49(7):1317-1325.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[2] Jansen JP, Gaugris S, Choy EH, Ostor A, Nash JT, Stam W. Cost effectiveness of etoricoxib versus celecoxib and non-selective NSAIDS in the treatment of ankylosing spondylitis. Pharmacoeconomics. 2010 Apr;28(4):323-344.    [ Link to PubMed ] 

[3] Fouque-Aubert A, Jette-Paulin L, Combescure C, Basch A, Tebib J, Gossec L. Serious infections in patients with ankylosing spondylitis with and without TNF blockers: A systematic review and meta analysis of randomised placebo-controlled trials. Ann Rheum Dis. 2010 Oct;69(10):1756-1761.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[4] Lee YH, Song GG. Lack of association of TNF-alpha promoter polymorphisms with ankylosing spondylitis: a meta-analysis. Rheumatology. 2009 Nov;48(11):1359-1362.     [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[5] Li B, Wang P, Li H. The association between TNF-alpha promoter polymorphisms and ankylosing spondylitis: A meta-analysis. Clin Rheum. 2010 Sep;29(9):983-990.     [ Link to Specialist Collection ] 


 

]]>

document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Commentary on Complementary and Alternative Therapy
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics & NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE THERAPY]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Commentary on Complementary and Alternative Therapy

Link to Contents

 

This commentary, prepared by Mr Andrew Roberts, is based upon the results of a literature search and is founded on the systematic review’s abstract or other summary, and the inclusion of a study in this update does not imply endorsement. The specialist collections do not accept responsibility for the content or quality of included studies.

 

Complementary Therapy

There is weak evidence that yoga may be effective in the management of back pain, sufficient that a prospective randomised trial sponsored by Arthritis Research UK has been initiated [1]. Systematic reviews of Chinese herbal medicine [2] and herbal treatments [3, 4], suggested weak evidence of benefit in chronic low back pain. Little evidence was found to support the use of spinal manipulation treatment [4] or internal qigong [5] in the management of back pain. A positive review of intradiscal ozone suggested good benefit from this treatment with very low complication rates and similar efficacy to surgical discectomy [6].


Acupuncture

Edzard Ernst examined the evidence to support acupuncture for a variety of musculoskeletal conditions and concluded that there was sufficient positive evidence of benefit to recommend acupuncture in low back pain [7], agreeing with two other reviews concerning the low back [4, 8] and one concerning neck pain [9]. In general, the quality of studies of acupuncture for low back pain is poor [10].


Chiropractic Therapy

Whilst spinal manipulation therapy alone appears to be ineffective [4], Walker examined chiropractry as a multimodal treatment, finding a small benefit in the short term only [11]. Anecdotal evidence exists of serious adverse events related to cervical manipulation resulting from vertebrobasilar and cord compromise however, Carlesso et al noted that trials of manipulation appeared to be deficient with regard to reporting adverse events making evaluation of risk uncertain [12]. 

 

Bibliography

[1] Cox H, Tilbrook H, Aplin J, Chuang LH, Hewitt C, Jayakody S, et al. A pragmatic multi-centred randomised controlled trial of yoga for chronic low back pain: trial protocol. Complement Ther Clin Pract. 2010 May;16(2):76-80.    [ Link to PubMed ]

[2] Cui X, Trinh K, Wang YJ. Chinese herbal medicine for chronic neck pain due to cervical degenerative disc disease. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2010;(1):CD006556.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

[3] Gagnier JJ. Evidence based review of natural health products for non-specific low back pain. Open Pain Journal. 2010;3(1):52-59.    [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

[4] Rubinstein SM, van Middelkoop M, Kuijpers T, Ostelo R, Verhagen AP, de Boer MR, et al. [5] Lee MS, Pittler MH, Ernst E. Internal qigong for pain conditions: a systematic review. J Pain. 2009 Nov;10(11):1121-1127.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[6] Steppan J, Meaders T, Muto M, Murphy KJ. A metaanalysis of the effectiveness and safety of ozone treatments for herniated lumbar discs. J Vasc Interv Radiol. 2010 Apr;21(4):534-548.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[7] Ernst E, Lee MS. Acupuncture for rheumatic conditions: An overview of systematic reviews. Rheumatology. 2010 Oct;49(10):1957-1961.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[8] Trigkilidas D. Acupuncture therapy for chronic lower back pain: a systematic review. Ann R Coll Surg Engl. 2010 Oct;92(7):595-8.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[9] Fu LM, Li JT, Wu WS. Randomized controlled trials of acupuncture for neck pain: systematic review and meta-analysis. J Altern Complement Med. 2009 Feb;15(2):133-145.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[10] Lewis K, Abdi S. Acupuncture for lower back pain: a review. Clin J Pain. 2010 Jan;26(1):60-69.    [ Link to PubMed ]

[11] Walker BF, French SD, Grant W, Green S. Combined chiropractic interventions for low-back pain. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2010;4:CD005427.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

[12] Carlesso LC, Gross AR, Santaguida PL, Burnie S, Voth S, Sadi J. Adverse events associated with the use of cervical manipulation and mobilization for the treatment of neck pain in adults: a systematic review. Man Ther. 2010 Oct;15(5):434-44.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

document.title: 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Commentary on Surgery
document.publisher: NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics & NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,MAJOR INFLAMMATORY,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY,SERONEGATIVE SPONDYLARTHROPATHIES,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Commentary on Surgery

Link to Contents

 

This commentary, prepared by Mr Andrew Roberts, is based upon the results of a literature search and is founded on the systematic review’s abstract or other summary, and the inclusion of a study in this update does not imply endorsement. The specialist collections do not accept responsibility for the content or quality of included studies.

 

Cervical Spine

A review of surgical treatment for cervical myelopathy revealed the trade offs in terms of restricted neck motion, late pain and complication rates such that the patient's priorities might influence the approach taken [1]. All modalities of treatment had a similar beneficial effect on long tract function. For multilevel encroachment by disc or ossified posterior longitudinal ligament (OPLL), anterior surgery gave a faster return to recovery than posterior surgery but with a higher rate of complications. At five years following surgery, there was little to choose between posterior and anterior approaches with the exception of OPLL where the ligament encroached more than 60% into the canal, in which case an anterior approach was advisable [2]. Occipitocervical arthrodesis can be accomplished by rod and screw constructs or posterior wiring but a systematic review suggested that rod/screw constructs were more effective for inflammatory pathologies, whilst wiring led to the best outcomes in neoplastic disease [3]. A systematic review by Wolfs et al, examined the management of the upper cervical spine in rheumatoid patients and found an absence of useful studies to guide recommendations [4].

Cervical radiculopathy surgery was reviewed in a Cochrane review and found to lack a large or robust evidence base with similar outcomes at one and three years compared with non-operative management [5]. Disc replacement is a well tried option in the lumbar spine but appears to offer little extra benefit when compared with arthrodesis in the cervical spine [6, 7].

 

Lumbar Disc Disease

In the lumbar spine, disc replacement is revealed as a developing technology that is associated with significant morbidity and complications when compared with interbody fusion [8, 9]. A large well controlled trial would be needed to settle the issue. Patients undergoing treatment for herniated discs are often depressed [10]. Whether depressed patients are more likely to exhibit high levels of disability, thus increasing their likelihood of being offered surgery was not explored. In a review of conservative treatment for lumbar disc protrusion with nerve root entrapment, the message remains the same as Weber's classic assessment - that surgery offers benefit in the short term but no advantage over expectant treatment in the long term [11].

 

Scoliosis

Pedicle screw fixation systems allow powerful correction of spinal deformity but come with certain complications, most notably malposition of the screws. Routine post-operative CT scanning reveals that one in six pedicle screws, on average, is malpositioned [12]. Other complications include pedicle fractures, tears of the dura and nerve root injury. Particularly in the thoracic spine, the potential for very serious complications exists. Computer guided screw placement, whilst more accurate, has not been demonstrated to reduce the risk of neurological injury [13].

Unlike scoliosis correction in the adolescent, a review of outcomes in adults highlighted a moderate improvement in disability scores with a fearsome 40% incidence of perioperative complications [14].

 

Spinal Trauma

Odontoid fractures through the base of the peg (type II) can be managed conservatively. In a systematic review of the literature, conservative treatment of type II odontoid fractures appeared satisfactory in patients under the age of 45 years with anterior and only moderate displacement [15]. Fixation of odontoid fractures in the elderly is associated with a 10% mortality rate and significant morbidity [16]. Anterior cervical spine surgery has a dysphagia rate of between 13% and 12% with higher rates in female patients and those undergoing multilevel procedures. Riley et al define the problem, but in the absence of any preventative strategy, the value of their review is to aid informed consent for patients contemplating anterior cervical surgery [17].

The management of spinal fractures often evokes heated discussion. Bellabarba conducted a systematic review of studies examining morbidity and mortality, comparing fixation of unstable thoracic spinal fractures within 72 hours of injury compared with delayed fixation, concluding that there is a reduction in morbidity and possibly mortality associated with early management [18]. After spinal surgery, prophylaxis with fractionated heparin has been viewed as a risk factor for epidural haematoma however, at prophylactic doses, Glotzbecker et al did not find compelling evidence of an increased risk [19].

 

Minimally Invasive Surgery

A review of percutaneous vertebroplasty for malignant spinal pathology found moderate evidence of benefit from vertebroplasty with weak evidence of efficacy of pre-operative embolisation in reducing blood loss during the procedure [20].

 

 

References

[1] Cunningham MR, Hershman S, Bendo J. Systematic review of cohort studies comparing surgical treatments for cervical spondylotic myelopathy. Spine. 2010 Mar;35(5):537-543.    [ Link to PubMed ]

[2] Liu T, Xu W, Cheng T, Yang HL. Anterior versus posterior surgery for multilevel cervical myelopathy, which one is better? A systematic review. Eur Spine J. 2010 Jun.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

[3] Winegar CD, Lawrence JP, Friel BC, et al. A systematic review of occipital cervical fusion: techniques and outcomes. J Neurosurg Spine. 2010 Jul;13(1):5-16.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[4] Wolfs JF, Kloppenburg M, Fehlings MG, van Tulder MW, Boers M, Peul WC. Neurologic outcome of surgical and conservative treatment of rheumatoid cervical spine subluxation: a systematic review. Arthritis Rheum. 2009 Dec;61(12):1743-1752.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[5] Nikolaidis I, Fouyas IP, Sandercock PA, Statham PF. Surgery for cervical radiculopathy or myelopathy. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2010 Jan;(1):CD001466.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

[6] Zechmeister I, Winkler R, Mad P. Artificial total disc replacement versus fusion for the cervical spine: a systematic review. Eur Spine J. 2010 Oct.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

[7] BCBSA. Artificial intervertebral disc arthroplasty for treatment of degenerative disc disease of the cervical spine. Technol Eval Cent Asses Program Exec Summ. 2009 Aug;24(3):1-4.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to full-text ]

[8] van den Eerenbeemt KD, Ostelo RW, van Royen BJ, PeulWC, van Tulder MW. Total disc replacement surgery for symptomatic degenerative lumbar disc disease: A systematic review of the literature. Eur Spine J. 2010 Aug;19(8):1262-1280.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

[9] Yajun W, Yue Z, Xiuxin H, Cui C. A meta-analysis of artificial total disc replacement versus fusion for lumbar degenerative disc disease. Eur Spine J. 2010 Aug;19(8):1250-1261.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ]

[15] Nourbakhsh A, Shi R, Vannemreddy P, Nanda A. Operative versus nonoperative management of acute odontoid Type II fractures: a meta-analysis. J Neurosurg Spine. 2009 Dec;11(6):651-8.    [ Link to Specialist Collection ] [ Link to journal full-text - PDF ]

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Horizon Scanning

Link to Contents

 

NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics have identified forthcoming guidelines, projects and reviews concerning spinal diseases.  These will establish the evidence which will be published in the future.


National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) 

  • Golimumab for the treatment of ankylosing spondylitis  (2011)

 

HTA Projects

  • Management strategies for sciatica  
  • Managing Injuries of the Neck Trial (MINT)

 

Cochrane Library - Protocols

  • Conservative interventions for treating work-related complaints of the arm, neck or shoulder in adults
  • Ergonomic design and training for preventing work-related musculoskeletal disorders of the upper limb and neck in adults
  • Patient positioning and braces for pain relief and spinal stability in metastatic cord compression in adults
  • Radiofrequency denervation for chronic low-back pain
  • Workplace interventions for low-back pain in workers
  • Botulinum toxin for low-back pain
  • Red flags to screen for vertebral fracture in patients presenting with low-back pain
  • Total disc replacement for chronic low-back pain
  • Surgical approaches for cervical spine facet dislocations
  • Spinal manipulative therapy for chronic low-back pain
  • Red flags to screen for malignancy in patients with low-back pain

document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,MAJOR INFLAMMATORY,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,NURSING,OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY,ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY,SERONEGATIVE SPONDYLARTHROPATHIES,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISABILITY MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Introduction and Contents

Published 13 December 2010

Introduction 

 

 

NHS Evidence –trauma and orthopaedics in conjunction with NHS Evidence -musculoskeletal have produced this 2010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases. As in previous years, we have included guidelines and systematic reviews which have been published within the last year. This Annual Evidence Update includes reviews covering disc surgery and minimally invasive surgery along with various therapies and treatments. This topic should be of interest to all health professionals working in this field.

 

Contents

  • Methodology
  • Results
    • Results Commentary by Mr Andrew Roberts
    • Commentary on Ankylosing Spondylitis by Dr Robin Butler
    • Commentary on Complementary and Alternative Therapy by Mr Andrew Roberts
    • Commentary on Surgery by Mr Andrew Roberts
  • Horizon scanning

 

Click here for more information on complementary and alternative therapies and 'back pain' from NHS Evidence - complementary and alternative medicine. 

 

Acknowledgements

We would like to acknowledge and thank Dr Robin Butler MD FRCP, Consultant Rheumatologist at Robert Jones & Agnes Hunt Orthopaedic & District Hospital NHS Trust and Mr Andrew Roberts, Paediatric Orthopaedic Surgeon and lead for the trauma and orthopaedics specialist collection for providing the commentaries.  Also, Mr Andrew Roberts for appraising the literature search which has enabled this Annual Evidence Updates to be produced. 

In addition, we would like to thank Ann Brocklehurst, Project Leader and Holly Tricker, Information Assistant for the Musculoskeletal and Trauma & Orthopaedics Specialist Collections for providing the literature searches and collating the information.

 

]]>

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - Methodology

Link to Contents

 

The 2010 Annual Evidence Update on spinal diseases was produced by NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics in conjunction with NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal. Our aim was to identify systematic reviews published in the last year.  

Systematic Reviews (after appraisal):  78  

 

Search Period
The final searches were conducted on the 28th October 2010. 

 

Databases searched:

PubMed

  • #1  Lumba* AND Spondyl*
  • #2  Facet AND Joint AND Osteoarth*
  • #3  Spondyl*
  • #4  Lumba* AND Disc AND Degenerati*
  • #5  Low AND Back AND (Pain OR Ache)
  • #6  Lumbago OR Sciatica
  • #7  #5 OR #6
  • #8  Ankylos* AND Spondyl*
  • #9  Bechterew* OR Marie Str*
  • #10 #8 OR #9
  • #11 Osteop* AND (Spin* OR Vertebra*) AND Fractur*
  • #12 Osteoporo* AND (Spine OR Spina*)
  • #13  #1 OR #2 OR #3 OR #4 OR #7 OR #10 OR #11 OR #12

The above search strategy was used with the Clinical Queries Filter limited to 1 year, human and English language. This resulted in 110 records retrieved. 

 

NHS Databases
Searched individually (AMED, CINAHL, EMBASE, MEDLINE) and limited to 2009 - current, using the search strategy below:

  • #1   review (pt)
  • #2  “meta analysis” (pt)
  • #3   systematic* and (review* OR overview*) (ti/ab)
  • #4   meta-analy* OR meta analy* OR metaanaly* (ti/ab)
  • #5   #1 OR #2 OR #3 OR #4
  • #6   Lumba* AND Spondyl*
  • #7   Facet AND Joint AND Osteoarth*
  • #8   Spondyl*
  • #9   Lumba* AND Disc AND Degenerati*#10
  • #10 Low AND Back AND (Pain OR Ache)
  • #11 Lumbago OR Sciatica
  • #12 Ankylos* AND Spondyl*
  • #13 Bechterew* OR Marie Str*
  • #14 Osteop* AND (Spin* OR Vertebra*) AND Fractur*
  • #15 Osteoporo* AND (Spine OR Spina*)
  • #16 #6 OR #7 OR #8 OR #9 OR#10 OR #11 OR #12 OR #13 OR #14 0R #15
  • #17 #5 AND #16

AMED  - 30 records retrieved

MEDLINE - 680 records retrieved

CINAHL - 139 records retrieved

EMBASE - 783 records retrieved

The following websites were also searched:

  • NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics
  • NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal

 and 73 records retrieved.

Systematic review identification criteria

Our aim was to identify all systematic reviews published on spinal diseases excluding neck for the last year. All citations from database searches were imported into Reference Manager and duplicates removed. The search results were then scanned. This involved scanning the titles, abstracts and full texts where available to identify potential systematic reviews.

To identify systematic reviews the definition used by Glossary of Cochrane Collaboration Terms was used:

 

“A review of a clearly formulated question that uses systematic and explicit methods to identify, select, and critically appraise relevant research, and to collect and analyse data from the studies that are included in the review. Statistical methods (meta-analysis) may or may not be used to analyse and summarise the results of the included studies.”

 

The final decision on whether to include a citation as being a valid systematic review was made by Mr Andrew Roberts, Clinical Lead for NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics. 

]]>

document.body:
111-12010 Annual Evidence Update on Spinal Diseases - ResultsLink to Contents

 

The results of the 'spinal diseases' search have been reviewed and grouped into the following topics:

  • Guidance (11)
  • Surgery
    • Cervical Spine (7)
    • Lumbar Disc Disease (4)
    • Scoliosis (3)
    • Spinal Trauma (5)
    • Minimally Invasive Surgery (1)
  • Complementary Therapies (6)
    • Acupuncture (5)
    • Chiropractic Therapy (3)
  • Behavioural Therapy (1)
  • Drugs (5)
    • TNF-inhibitor (4)
  • Therapy (16)
  • Diagnosis
    • Pain (4)
    • Trauma (1)
  • Ankylosing Spondylitis (5)
  • Aetiology and Epidemiology (12)
  • Disability Measures (2)

Please note that the inclusion of citations in this list does not imply endorsements.  NHS Evidence - musculoskeletal and NHS Evidence - trauma and orthopaedics do not accept responsibility for the content or quality of the included or excluded studies.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A century of spine surgery: what can patients expect?
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,ADOLESCENT SCOLIOSIS,SURGERY]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Study Design:
Systematic Review.

Purpose:
To evaluate the hypothesis that spinal fusion surgery is an effective method to address spinal deformity-associated clinical problems, including magnitude of curvature (Cobb angle), pulmonary dysfunction, and pain.

Methods:
A systematic review was carried out using Science Citation Index (SCI) Expanded (1900 - present), Social Sciences Citation Index (1956 - present), Arts and Humanities Citation Index (1965 - present), Medline (1950 - present) and PubMed Central databases (1887 - present) to access information regarding efficacy of spine surgery in preventing or improving the health and function of patients diagnosed with scoliosis in adolescence.

Results:
Since 1950, more than 12,600 articles on scoliosis have been published, and nearly 50% (5721) focus on methods, rationale, outcome, and complications of surgical intervention. Among these, 82 articles have documented outcome for groups of > or =10 patients, treated for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis, and followed for at least 2 years after treatment. These data provide an overview of the impact of spine surgery on scoliosis for 5780 patients as surgery methods and approaches have evolved.

Conclusion:
For most patients, a reduced magnitude of spinal curvature can be achieved through one or more spinal fusion surgeries. There is no evidence to support the premise that this result is correlated with improved pulmonary function or reduced pain.


Ref: Disabil Rehabil. 2008;30(4):808-17.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A comparison of regional and general anaesthesia for total replacement of the hip or knee: a meta-analysis
document.publisher: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (British Volume)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,ARTHROPLASTY,ANAESTHESIA,HIP AND PELVIS,KNEE,THROMBOEMBOLISM]]>
document.body:
Abstract

We performed a meta-analysis to evaluate the relative efficacy of regional and general anaesthesia in patients undergoing total hip or knee replacement. A comprehensive search for relevant studies was performed in PubMed (1966 to April 2008), EMBASE (1969 to April 2008) and the Cochrane Library. Only randomised studies comparing regional and general anaesthesia for total hip or knee replacement were included. We identified 21 independent, randomised clinical trials. A random-effects model was used to calculate all effect sizes. Pooled results from these trials showed that regional anaesthesia reduces the operating time (odds ratio (OR) -0.19; 95% confidence interval (CI) -0.33 to -0.05), the need for transfusion (OR 0.45; 95% CI 0.22 to 0.94) and the incidence of thromboembolic disease (deep-vein thrombosis OR 0.45, 95% CI 0.24 to 0.84; pulmonary embolism OR 0.46, 95% CI 0.29 to 0.80). Regional anaesthesia therefore seems to improve the outcome of patients undergoing total hip or knee replacement.

 

Ref: J Bone Joint Surg Br. 2009 Jul;91(7):935-42

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A Competency Based Curriculum 2007 - Specialist Training in Trauma and Orthopaedics
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,EDUCATION AND REFERENCE RESOURCES]]>
document.body:
This Curriculum was produced to guide Orthopaedic training in the UK by providing accessible information for both the trainee and the trainer, who are seen as its primary audience.

The Curriculum aims to make the links between the surgical education process as a whole and assessment processes in particular absolutely clear. It is written bearing in mind that all of its proposals must be feasible in the present workplace not just in an aspirational future.

Although the Curriculum is a technical document written primarily for a professional orthopaedic audience it also seeks to provide transparent guidance for all, in particular the general public and patients.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A concept for comprehensively measuring health, function and quality of life following orthopaedic interventions of the upper extremity
document.publisher: Archives of Orthopaedic and Trauma Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,SHOULDER,ELBOW,HAND AND WRIST,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Abstract

The view that subjective complaints rather than "objective" measurements decide on whether to consult the doctor or allow for an intervention to be carried out, should contribute to the decision-making process. This is especially true in diseases with multiple joint impairments. Although a variety of patient self-assessment scores exists, no gold standard is available to measure function and quality of life (QoL) after interventions at the upper extremity. The goal of our concept is to establish a comprehensive score set where patients should rate their generic health resp. quality of life (QoL), function of the upper extremity and specific joint function including activities of daily living, function and pain. A comparison with normative data should be possible in order to estimate how the subjective results of the patient when compared to "healthy" people in the general population. Score sets for measuring intervention effect at the shoulder, elbow and the hand were established after previous methodological testing within an interdisciplinary research project. The provisional sets were defined following a systematic literature search. Each set received a score of measuring the quality of life (SF-36), the whole function of the arm (DASH) and the specific joint function (SPADI/ASES for shoulder, PREE/mASES for the elbow and PRWE/custom for the hand). Individual scores were translated, if necessary according to AAOS-guidelines, and tested for reliability and construct validity. All three score sets were then systematically tested in cross-sectional studies. In addition, characteristic values such as minimal detectable difference and effect size could already be determined in the shoulder set in a long-term study. Definite score sets were defined, which allow quantification of the intervention effect at the upper extremity on function and quality of life after.

 

Ref: Arch Orthop Trauma Surg. 2009 Jan;129(1):113-8. Epub 2008 Sep 11.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A critical review of guidelines for low back pain treatment
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,LOW BACK PAIN,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Main problem:
Little is known about the methodological quality of guidelines for low back pain treatment. We evaluated the methods used by the developers according to established standards.

Methods:
PubMed, guideline databases, and the World Wide Web were used to identify guidelines. Seventeen guidelines met the inclusion criteria: interventions for low back pain stated, recommendations based on or explicitly linked to evidence, and English version available. Guidelines were evaluated independently by two appraisers using a practical tool for this purpose, Users' Guides to the Medical Literature, and the Appraisal of Guidelines for Research and Evaluation (AGREE) instrument.

Results:
Thirteen guidelines (76%) specified the most important therapies applied, but only nine (53%) included a complete description of the target population. Explicit processes to identify, select, and combine evidence were described in only six guidelines (35%). Few guidelines (3; 18%) explicitly considered all main outcomes when formulating therapeutic recommendations, and none contained a process to determine the relative value of different outcomes. Methodological criteria for grading the strength of the recommendations varied, and were often insufficiently specified. None of the guidelines assessed the impact of uncertainty associated with the evidence and values used. According to AGREE the quality score was highest for the scope and purpose, and clarity and presentation domains, and lowest for editorial independence and applicability. With regard to the recommendations, there was consensus for some of the interventions for acute pain (analgesics and NSAIDs, maintaining physical activity, and avoiding excessive bed rest), but explicit recommendations were lacking or ambiguous for 41% of the interventions. Most of the guidelines did not contemplate specific recommendations for chronic pain.

Conclusion:
A small number of the available guidelines for low back pain treatment achieved acceptable results for specific quality criteria. In general, the methods to develop the guidelines' therapeutic recommendations need to be more rigorous, more explicit and better explained. In addition, greater importance should be placed on the recommendations for chronic pain.

Link to PubMed abstract

Ref: Eur Spine J. 2006 May;15(5):543-53.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A critical review of the American Pain Society Clinical practice guidelines for interventional techniques: part 2. Therapeutic interventions
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY,PAIN MANAGEMENT,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DISC DISORDERS,LOW BACK PAIN,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,SURGERY,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Background:
Clinical guidelines are a constructive response to the reality that practicing physicians require assistance in assimilating and applying the exponentially expanding, often contradictory, body of medical knowledge. They attempt to define practices that meet the needs of most patients under most circumstances. Ideally, specific clinical recommendations contained within practice guidelines are systematically developed by expert panels who have access to all the available evidence, have an understanding of the clinical problem, and have clinical experience with the procedure being assessed, as well as knowledge of relevant research methods. The recent development of American Pain Society (APS) guidelines has created substantial controversy because of their perceived lack of objective analysis and recommendations perceived to be biased due to conflicts of interest.

Objectives:
To formally and carefully assess the APS guidelines' evidence synthesis for low back pain for therapeutic interventions using the same methodology utilized by the APS authors. The interventions examined were therapeutic interventions for managing low back pain, including epidural injections, adhesiolysis, facet joint interventions, and spinal cord stimulation.

Methods:
A literature search by 2 authors was carried out utilizing appropriate databases from 1966 through July 2008. Articles in which conflicts arose were reviewed and mediated by a third author to arrive at a consensus. Selections of manuscripts and methodologic quality assessment was also performed by at least 2 authors utilizing the same criteria applied in the APS guidelines. The guideline reassessment process included the evaluation of individual studies and systematic reviews and their translation into practice recommendations.

Results:
The conclusions of APS and our critical assessment based on grading of good, fair, and poor, agreed that there is fair evidence for spinal cord stimulation in post lumbar surgery syndrome, and poor evidence for lumbar intraarticular facet joint injections, lumbar interlaminar epidural injections, caudal epidural steroids for conditions other than disc herniation or radiculitis, sacroiliac joint injections, intradiscal electrothermal therapy, endoscopic adhesiolysis, and intrathecal therapy. However, our assessment of APS guidelines for other interventional techniques, utilizing their own criteria, showed fair evidence for therapeutic lumbar facet joint nerve blocks, caudal epidural injections in disc herniation or radiculitis, percutaneous adhesiolysis in post lumbar surgery syndrome, radiofrequency neurotomy, and transforaminal epidural injections in radiculitis. Also it is illustrated that inclusion of latest literature will change the conclusions, with improved grading - caudal epidural, adhesiolysis, and lumbar facet joint nerve blocks from fair to good or poor to fair. The present critical assessment review illustrates that APS guidelines have utilized multiple studies inappropriately and have excluded appropriate studies. Our integrity assessment shows deep concerns that the APS guidelines illustrating significant methodologic failures which raise concerns about transparency, accountability, consistency, and independence.

Conclusion:
The current reassessment, using appropriate methodology, shows evidence similar to APS guidelines for several procedures, but differs extensively from published APS guidelines for multiple other procedures including caudal epidural injections, lumbar facet joint nerve blocks, lumbar radiofrequency neurotomy, and percutaneous adhesiolysis.

Link to PubMed abstract

 

Ref: Pain Physician. 2010 Jul;13(4):E215-64.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A family history of fracture and fracture risk: a meta-analysis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMA,METABOLIC BONE DISEASE,HIP FRACTURES,HIP AND PELVIS,ACCIDENT PREVENTION,FRAGILITY FRACTURES]]>
document.body:
Abstract
The aims of the present study were to determine whether a parental history of any fracture or hip fracture specifically are significant risk factors for future fracture in an international setting, and to explore the effects of age, sex and bone mineral density (BMD) on this risk. We studied 34,928 men and women from seven prospectively studied cohorts followed for 134,374 person-years. The cohorts comprised the EPOS/EVOS study, CaMos, the Rotterdam Study, DOES and cohorts at Sheffield, Rochester and Gothenburg. The effect of family history of osteoporotic fracture or of hip fracture in first-degree relatives, BMD and age on all clinical fracture, osteoporotic fracture and hip fracture risk alone was examined using Poisson regression in each cohort and for each sex. The results of the different studies were merged from the weighted beta coefficients. A parental history of fracture was associated with a modest but significantly increased risk of any fracture, osteoporotic fracture and hip fracture in men and women combined. The risk ratio (RR) for any fracture was 1.17 (95% CI=1.07-1.28), for any osteoporotic fracture was 1.18 (95% CI=1.06-1.31), and for hip fracture was 1.49 (95% CI=1.17-1.89). The risk ratio was higher at younger ages but not significantly so. No significant difference in risk was seen between men and women with a parental history for any fracture (RR=1.17 and 1.17, respectively) or for an osteoporotic fracture (RR=1.17 and 1.18, respectively). For hip fracture, the risk ratios were somewhat higher, but not significantly higher, in men than in women (RR=2.02 and 1.38, respectively). A family history of hip fracture in parents was associated with a significant risk both of all osteoporotic fracture (RR 1.54; 95CI=1.25-1.88) and of hip fracture (RR=2.27; 95% CI=1.47-3.49). The risk was not significantly changed when BMD was added to the model. We conclude that a parental history of fracture (particularly a family history of hip fracture) confers an increased risk of fracture that is independent of BMD. Its identification on an international basis supports the use of this risk factor in case-finding strategies.

Ref: Bone. 2004 Nov;35(5):1029-37

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A literature review of randomized clinical trials of intravenous acetaminophen (paracetamol) for acute postoperative pain
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,SURGERY,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Introduction:
This study's objective was to systematically review the literature to assess analgesic outcomes of intravenous (IV) acetaminophen for acute postoperative pain in adults.

Methods:
We searched Medline and the Cochrane library (January 1, 2000 to January 17, 2010, date of last search) for prospective, randomized, controlled trials (RCTs) of IV acetaminophen vs. either an active comparator or placebo.

Results:
Sixteen articles from 9 countries published between 2005 and 2010 met inclusion criteria and had a total of 1,464 patients. Median sample size = 54 patients (range 25 to 165) and median follow-up = 1 day (range 1 hour to 7 days). Four of the 16 articles had 3 arms in the study. One article had 4 arms. As a result, 22 study comparisons were analyzed: IV acetaminophen to an active comparator (n = 8 studies) and IV acetaminophen to placebo (n = 14 studies). The RCTs were of high methodological quality with Jadad median score = 5. In 7 of 8 active comparator studies (IV parecoxib [n = 3 studies], IV metamizol [n = 4], oral ibuprofen [n = 1]), IV acetaminophen had similar analgesic outcomes as the active comparator. Twelve of the 14 placebo studies found that IV acetaminophen patients had improved analgesia. Ten of those 14 studies reported less opioid consumption, a lower percentage of patients rescuing, or a longer time to first rescue with IV acetaminophen. Formal meta-analysis pooling was not performed because the studies had different primary end points, and the IV acetaminophen dosing regimens varied in dose, and duration and timing.

Conclusion:
In aggregate, these data indicate that IV acetaminophen is an effective analgesic across a variety of surgical procedures.

 

Ref: Pain Pract. 2010 Nov 28. doi: 10.1111/j.1533-2500.2010.00426.x. [Epub ahead of print]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of amputation versus limb salvage in mangled lower limb injuries-The patient perspective
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,TRAUMA,AMPUTATION]]>
document.body:
Abstract

This meta-analysis evaluates the quality of life in post-traumatic amputees in comparison with limb salvage. Studies included in this meta-analysis had a minimum of 24 months of follow-up and used a validated quality-of-life outcome assessment scale (Short Form-36 or Sickness Impact Profile) for physical and psychological outcomes. Two reviewers performed the search and data extraction independent of each other. A total of 214 studies were identified; 11 fulfilled the inclusion criteria; thus, 1138 patients were available for meta-analysis (769 amputees and 369 cases of reconstruction). The meta-analysis demonstrated that lower limb reconstruction is more acceptable psychologically to patients with severe lower limb trauma compared with amputation, even though the physical outcome for both management pathways was more or less the same.

 

Ref: Injury. 2010 Jun 30. [Epub ahead of print]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of artificial total disc replacement versus fusion for lumbar degenerative disc disease
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DISC DISORDERS,LOW BACK PAIN,SURGERY,ARTHROPLASTY,ARTHRODESIS]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Lumbar fusion has been developed for several decades and became the standard surgical treatment for symptomatic lumbar degenerative disc disease (DDD). Artificial total disc replacement (TDR), as an alternative for spinal arthrodesis, is becoming more commonly employed treating lumbar DDD. It is still uncertain whether TDR is more effective and safer than lumbar fusion. To systematically compare the effectiveness and safety of TDR to that of the fusion for the treatment of lumbar DDD, we performed a meta-analysis. Cochrane review methods were used to analyze all relevant randomized controlled trials published up to July 2009. Five relevant randomized controlled trials involving 837 patients were identified. Patients in TDR group have sightly better functioning and less back or leg pain without clinical significance, and significantly higher satisfaction status in TDR group compared with lumbar fusion group at the 2-year follow-up. But these outcomes are highly influenced by the study with BAK cage interbody fusion, the function/pain and patient satisfaction status are no longer significantly different between two groups after excluding this study. At 5 years, these outcomes are not significantly different between comparing groups. The complication and reoperation rate of two groups are similar both at 2 and at 5 years. In conclusion, TDR does not show significant superiority for the treatment of lumbar DDD compared with fusion. The benefits of motion preservation and the long-term complications are still unable to be concluded. More high-quality RCTs with long-term follow-up are needed.

 

Ref: Eur Spine J. 2010 19(8):1250-1261. Epub 2010 Apr 4.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of circumferential fusion versus instrumented posterolateral fusion in the lumbar spine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,OSTEOARTHRITIS,DISC DISORDERS,SURGERY,PAIN MANAGEMENT,ARTHRODESIS]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Study design:
A meta-analysis of circumferential fusion versus instrumented posterolateral fusion (PLF) in the lumbar spine.

Objective:
To compare the clinical efficacy of circumferential fusion and instrumented PLF and to collate the scientific evidence to find a useful fusion method.

Summary of background data:
Clinical results, advantages, and postoperative complications of circumferential fusion and instrumented PLF were shown in many studies. However, there are different opinions among surgeons concerning the preferred method for the 2 fusion methods.

Methods:
A highly sensitive search strategy was used to identify all published randomized controlled trials up to December 2007. A criteria list taken from Koes et al was used to evaluate the risk of bias of the included studies. The 5 questions that were recommended by the Cochrane Back Review Group were used to evaluate the clinical relevance. Cochrane methodology was used for the results of this meta-analysis.

Results:
Four randomized controlled trials of surgery for lumbar degenerative disease were identified. No significant difference was found in the primary beneficial clinical outcome (odds ratios[OR]: 0.96, 95% confidence limits[95% CI]: [0.59, 1.55], [P = 0.87]). Significant difference was found in the complication rate (OR: 1.89, 95% CI: [1.14, 3.14], [P = 0.01]), which reflects the primary harm outcome. In the secondary outcomes, significant differences were found between circumferential fusion and instrumented PLF in the fusion rate (OR: 2.11, 95% CI: [1.06, 4.19], [P = 0.03]), the reoperation rate (OR: 0.44, 95% CI: [0.25, 0.77], [P = 0.004]), and the amount of blood loss (WMD = 349.95, 95% CI: [138.26, 561.64], [P = 0.001]). No significant difference was found the operating time (WMD = 90.24, 95% CI: [-9.71, 190.20], [P = 0.08]).

Conclusion:
Compared with instrumented PLF, circumferential fusion can increase the fusion rate and reduce the reoperation rate, but it can also increase the complication rate and the amount of blood loss. No significant difference was found in the global assessment of clinical outcome about the 2 fusion procedures.

 

Ref: Spine (Phila Pa 1976). 2009 Aug 1;34(17):E618-25

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of design- and manufacturing-related parameters influencing the wear behavior of metal-on-metal hip joint replacements
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,ARTHROPLASTY,HIP AND PELVIS]]>
document.body:
Abstract

This article aims to clarify the influence of design- and manufacturing-related parameters on wear of metal-on-metal (MoM) joint bearings. A database search for publications on wear simulator studies of MoM bearings was performed. The results of published studies were normalized; groups with individual parameters were defined and analyzed statistically. Fifty-six investigations studying a total of 200 implants were included in the analysis. Clearance, head size, carbon content, and manufacturing method were analyzed as parameters influencing MoM wear. This meta-analysis revealed a strong influence of clearance on running-in wear for implants of 36-mm diameter and an increase in steady-state wear of heat treated components.

Ref: J Orthop Res. 2009 May 26. [Epub ahead of print]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of hamstring autografts versus bone-patellar tendon-bone autografts for reconstruction of the anterior cruciate ligament
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPORTS INJURIES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMATIC,ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT RUPTURE,SURGERY,KNEE,LIGAMENT DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Abstract

The objective of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of hamstring (HT) autografts versus bone-patellar tendon-bone (BPTB) autografts for reconstruction of the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, EMBASE and the Chinese Biomedicine Database (CBM) for published randomised clinical trials (RCTs) relevant to ACL reconstruction comparing HT and BPTB autografts. Data analyses were performed with Cochrane Collaboration's RevMan 5.0. A total of 23 reports of 19 randomised controlled trials (RCTs) (1643 patients) met the inclusion criteria. Outcomes favouring BPTB autografts were found in terms of KT-1000 arithmometer values, negative rates of Lachman tests and negative rates of Pivot tests. Outcome measures that favoured HT autografts included anterior knee pain, kneeling pain and extension loss. There was no statistical difference of postoperative graft failure. Overall, postoperative complications of the knee joint were lower for HT autografts than for BPTB autografts, and BPTB autografts were superior to HT autografts in resuming stability of the knee joint, but four-strand HT combined with application of the modern endobutton HT graft-fixation technique could increase knee-joint stability.

 

Ref: Knee. 2010 Sep 15. [Epub ahead of print]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of milk intake and fracture risk: low utility for case finding
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMA,FRACTURE,METABOLIC BONE DISEASE,ACCIDENT PREVENTION,FRAGILITY FRACTURES]]>
document.body:
A low intake of calcium is widely considered to be a risk factor for future fracture.

Objective
The aim of this study was to quantify this risk on an international basis and to explore the effect of age, gender and bone mineral density (BMD) on this risk.

Conclusion
A self-reported low intake of milk is not associated with any marked increase in fracture risk and that the use of this risk indicator is of little or no value in case-finding strategies.

Ref: Osteoporos Int. 2005 Jul;16(7):799-804

NB: The full-text of this article is available through the NLH Full-Text Journals 1 year after publication

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of open versus arthroscopic Bankart repair using suture anchors
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,TRAUMA,SHOULDER,SHOULDER INSTABILITY,ARTHROSCOPY,SOFT TISSUE TRAUMA]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Purpose of this study is to conduct a meta-analysis comparing the results of open and arthroscopic Bankart repair using suture anchors in recurrent traumatic anterior shoulder instability. Using Medline Pubmed, Cochrane and Embase databases we performed a search of all published articles. We included only studies that compared open and arthroscopic repair using suture anchors. Statistical analysis was performed using chi-square test. Six studies met the inclusion criteria. The total number of patients was 501, 234 suture anchors and 267 open. The rate of recurrent instability in the arthroscopic group was 6% versus 6.7% in the open group; rate of reoperation was 4.7% in the arthroscopic group vs. 6.6% in open (difference not statistically significant). The difference was statistically significant only in the studies after 2002 (2.9% of recurrence in the arthroscopic group vs. 9.2% in open; 2.2% of reoperation in the arthroscopic group vs. 9.2% in open). Results regarding function couldn't be combined because of non-homogeneous scores reported in the original articles, but the arthroscopic treatment led to better functional results. Arthroscopic repair using suture anchors results in similar redislocation and reoperation rate compared to open Bankart repair; however, we need larger and more homogeneous prospective studies to confirm these findings.

Link to PubMed abstract

 

Ref: Knee Surg Sports Traumatol Arthrosc. 2010 Dec;18(12):1742-7. Epub 2010 Mar 17.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of previous fracture and subsequent fracture risk
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMA,FRACTURE,HIP AND PELVIS,HIP FRACTURES,METABOLIC BONE DISEASE,ACCIDENT PREVENTION,FRAGILITY FRACTURES]]>
document.body:
Previous fracture is a well-documented risk factor for future fracture.

Objective
To quantify this risk on an international basis and to explore the relationship of this risk with age, sex, and bone mineral density (BMD).

Conclusion
Previous history of fracture confers an increased risk of fracture of substantial importance beyond that explained by measurement of BMD. Its validation on an international basis permits the use of this risk factor in case finding strategies.

Ref: Bone. 2004 Aug;35(2):375-82

 

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A metaanalysis of the effectiveness and safety of ozone treatments for herniated lumbar discs
document.publisher: Journal of Vascular and Interventional Radiology
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DISC DISORDERS,SURGERY]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Purpose:
To determine statistically significant effects of oxygen/ozone treatment of herniated discs with respect to pain, function, and complication rate.

Materials and methods:
Random-effects metaanalyses were used to estimate outcomes for oxygen/ozone treatment of herniated discs. A literature search provided relevant studies that were weighted by a study quality score. Separate metaanalyses were performed for visual analog scale (VAS), Oswestry Disability Index (ODI), and modified MacNab outcome scales, as well as for complication rate. Institutional review board approval was not required for this retrospective analysis.

Results:
Twelve studies were included in the metaanalyses. The inclusion/exclusion criteria, patient demographics, clinical trial rankings, treatment procedures, outcome measures, and complications are summarized. Metaanalyses were performed on the oxygen/ozone treatment results for almost 8,000 patients from multiple centers. The mean improvement was 3.9 for VAS and 25.7 for ODI. The likelihood of showing improvement on the modified MacNab scale was 79.7%. The means for the VAS and ODI outcomes are well above the minimum clinically important difference and the minimum (significant) detectable change. The likelihood of complications was 0.064%.

Conclusions:
Oxygen/ozone treatment of herniated discs is an effective and extremely safe procedure. The estimated improvement in pain and function is impressive in view of the broad inclusion criteria, which included patients ranging in age from 13 to 94 years with all types of disc herniations. Pain and function outcomes are similar to the outcomes for lumbar discs treated with surgical discectomy, but the complication rate is much lower (<0.1%) and the recovery time is significantly shorter.

 

Ref: J Vasc Interv Radiol. 2010 Apr;21(4):534-48. Epub 2010 Feb 25.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of the Gamma nail and dynamic hip screw in treating peritrochanteric fractures.
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,TRAUMA,FRACTURE,HIP AND PELVIS,HIP FRACTURES,FEMORAL FRACTURES]]>
document.body:
Abstract

The objective of this meta-analysis was to compare the fixation outcome of the Gamma nail and dynamic hip screw (DHS) in treating peritrochanteric fractures. Relevant randomised controlled studies were included, and the search strategy followed the requirements of the Cochrane Library Handbook. Methodological quality was assessed and data were extracted independently. Seven studies involving 1,257 fractures were included which compared the effect of the Gamma nail and DHS. The results showed a higher rate of postoperative femoral shaft fracture with the Gamma nail compared to the DHS [relative risk (RR): 7.27, 95% confidence interval (CI): 2.83-18.70, P < 0.0001] but no statistical differences in wound infection (RR: 1.02, 95% CI: 0.56-1.86), mortality (RR: 1.00, 95% CI: 0.81-1.24), re-operation (RR: 1.64, 95% CI: 0.91-2.95) and walking independently after rehabilitation (RR: 0.89, 95% CI: 0.60-1.33). It seemed that there were no obvious advantages of the Gamma nail over the DHS in treating peritrochanteric fractures.

 

Ref: Int Orthop. 2010 Mar;34(3):323-8. Epub 2009 Apr 29.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of the incidence of anterior cruciate ligament tears as a function of gender, sport, and a knee injury-reduction regimen
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SOFT TISSUE RHEUMATISM,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPORTS INJURIES,TRAUMATIC,ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT RUPTURE,SPORTS MEDICINE,KNEE DISORDERS,KNEE,LIGAMENT DISORDERS]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Purpose:
The literature has shown that anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear rates vary by gender, by sport, and in response to injury-reduction training programs. However, there is no consensus as to the magnitudes of these tear rates or their variations as a function of these variables. For example, the female-male ACL tear ratio has been reported to be as high as 9:1. Our purpose was to apply meta-analysis to the entire applicable literature to generate accurate estimates of the true incidences of ACL tear as a function of gender, sport, and injury-reduction training.

Methods:
A PubMed literature search was done to identify all studies dealing with ACL tear incidence. Bibliographic cross-referencing was done to identify additional articles. Meta-analytic principles were applied to generate ACL incidences as a function of gender, sport, and prior injury-reduction training.

Results:
Female-male ACL tear incidences ratios were as follows: basketball, 3.5; soccer, 2.67; lacrosse, 1.18; and Alpine skiing, 1.0. The collegiate soccer tear rate was 0.32 for female subjects and 0.12 for male subjects. For basketball, the rates were 0.29 and 0.08, respectively. The rate for recreational Alpine skiers was 0.63, and that for experts was 0.03, with no gender variance. The two volleyball studies had no ACL tears. Training reduced the ACL tear incidence in soccer by 0.24 but did not reduce it at all in basketball.

Conclusions:
Female subjects had a roughly 3 times greater incidence of ACL tears in soccer and basketball versus male subjects. Injury-reduction programs were effective for soccer but not basketball. Recreational Alpine skiers had the highest incidences of ACL tear, whereas expert Alpine skiers had the lowest incidences. Volleyball may in fact be a low-risk sport rather than a high-risk sport. Alpine skiers and lacrosse players had no gender difference for ACL tear rate. Year-round female athletes who play soccer and basketball have an ACL tear rate of approximately 5%.

 

Ref: Arthroscopy. 2007 Dec;23(12):1320-1325.e6.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A meta-analysis of tourniquet assisted arthroscopic knee surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPORTS INJURIES,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMATIC,ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT RUPTURE,SURGERY,KNEE,LIGAMENT DISORDERS,ARTHROSCOPY]]>
document.body:
Abstract

The purpose was to compare the intra- and post-operative outcomes of tourniquet assisted to non-tourniquet-assisted surgery during arthroscopic knee procedures. A systematic review was undertaken of the electronic databases MEDLINE, CINAHL, AMED and EMBASE, in addition to a review of unpublished material and a hand search of pertinent orthopaedic journals. The evidence-base was critically appraised using the Cochrane Bone, Joint and Muscle Trauma Group quality assessment tool. Study heterogeneity was statistically measured using the Chi(2) and I(2) statistical tests. When appropriate, a random-effect meta-analysis was undertaken to pool the results of the primary studies assessing the mean difference of each outcome. Nine studies were identified evaluating seven outcome measures and parameters. Arthroscopic ACL reconstruction knee surgery with a tourniquet experienced less operative visualisation difficulties compared to surgery without a tourniquet. There was no significant difference between tourniquet and non-tourniquet arthroscopic knee surgery for all other outcomes. The evidence-base exhibited a number of methodological limitations. There is limited evidence to suggest that a tourniquet assists in arthroscopic knee surgery. The methodological quality of the present evidence-base remains weak. Further study is required to answer this research question.

 

Ref: Knee. 2009 Oct;16(5):317-21. Epub 2009 Feb 23.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A 'plane' explanation of anterior cruciate ligament injury mechanisms: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPORTS INJURIES,TRAUMATIC,ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT RUPTURE,TRAUMA,KNEE,LIGAMENT DISORDERS,SOFT TISSUE TRAUMA]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Although intrinsic and extrinsic risk factors for anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury have been explored extensively, the factors surrounding the inciting event and the biomechanical mechanisms underlying ACL injury remain elusive. This systematic review summarizes all the relevant data and clarifies the strengths and weaknesses of the literature regarding ACL injury mechanisms. The hypothesis is that most ACL injuries do not occur via solely sagittal, frontal or transverse plane mechanisms. Electronic database literature searches of PubMed MEDLINE (1966-2008), CINAHL (1982-2008) and SportDiscus (1985-2008) were used for the systematic review to identify any studies in the literature that examined ACL injury mechanisms. Methodological approaches that describe and evaluate ACL injury mechanisms included athlete interviews, arthroscopic studies, clinical imaging and physical exam tests, video analysis, cadaveric studies, laboratory tests (motion analysis, electromyography) and mathematical modelling studies. One hundred and ninety-eight studies associated with ACL injury mechanisms were identified and provided evidence regarding plane of injury, with evidence supporting sagittal, frontal and/or transverse plane mechanisms of injury. Collectively, the studies indicate that it is highly probable that ACL injuries are more likely to occur during multi-planar rather than single-planar mechanisms of injury.

 

Ref: Sports Med. 2010 Sep 1;40(9):729-46.

]]>

document.title: A review and proposal for a core set of factors for prospective cohorts in low back pain: a consensus statement
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,LOW BACK PAIN]]>
document.body:
No abstract available.

Ref: Arthritis Rheum. 2008 Jan 15;59(1):14-24.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A review of instruments assessing participation in persons with spinal cord injury
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,SPINAL CORD INJURY]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Study Design:
Systematic Review.

Objective:
To critically review instruments that assess participation in persons with spinal cord injury (SCI).Setting:Vancouver, British Columbia.

Methods:
Four electronic databases (MEDLINE/PubMed, CINAHL, EMBASE and PsychInfo) were searched for studies published between 1980 and March 2008. Instruments were included if information was published in English in at least one peer-reviewed journal on its measurement properties (reliability, validity and responsiveness) in a sample that included adults with SCI. Instruments were evaluated using criteria proposed for disability outcome measures.

Results:
Six instruments were included: Craig Handicap Assessment and Reporting Technique (CHART); Impact on Participation and Autonomy Questionnaire (IPA); Assessment of Life Habits Scale (Life-H); Occupational Performance History Interview; Physical Activity Recall Assessment for People with Spinal Cord Injury; and Reintegration to Normal Living Index. Evidence supporting the reliability of the instruments was reported for four of the six instruments and was adequate. Validity was assessed in all the instruments. Only the Life-H and CHART have been compared with each other. No evidence on responsiveness was available.

Conclusion:
The instruments differ in how participation is operationalized. Currently, the CHART that measures objective aspects of participation has the most evidence supporting its measurement properties. More evidence is becoming available for instruments such as the IPA, which consider the person's perspective. It is important to determine what information about participation is required before selecting an instrument.

 

Ref: Spinal Cord. 2009 Feb 24. [Epub ahead of print].

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: A systematic literature review of nonsurgical treatment in adult scoliosis
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,COMPLEMENTARY/ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY,ORTHOTICS/AIDS AND EQUIPMENT,PHYSIOTHERAPY,SPINAL PROBLEMS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,PHYSIOTHERAPY,OCCUPATIONAL THERAPY,ORTHOTICS,DISABILITY MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
ABSTRACT

Study Design:
A formal systematic review of the literature for conservative treatment of adult deformity was performed.

Objective:
To evaluate evidence for the efficacy and effectiveness of proposed conservative treatment options in adult deformity.

Summary:
Adult deformity is a major demographic health issue in the geriatric population in both the United States and the world communities. Surgeons are often very conservative in the treatment of adult scoliosis because of the complication rates associated with the surgeries and the marginal bone quality endemic to this population. A prerequisite to surgical intervention is usually failure of all appropriate conservative care. There is currently a lack of consensus on the most efficacious conservative treatments for adult deformity.

Methods:
