document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: What is the evidence for total knee arthroplasty in young patients?: A systematic review of the literature
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,CHILDHOOD,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,ARTHROPLASTY]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Background:
TKA is commonly performed to treat advanced inflammatory and degenerative knee arthritis. With increasing use in younger patients, it is important to define the best practices to enhance clinical performance and implant longevity.

Questions/purposes:
We systematically reviewed the literature to assess: (1) how TKAs perform in young patients; (2) whether the TKA is a durable procedure for young patients, and (3) what guidance the literature outlines for TKA in young patients.

Methods:
We searched the literature between 1950 and 2009 for all studies reporting on TKAs for patients younger than 55 years that documented clinical and radiographic assessments with a minimum 2-year followup. Thirteen studies, reporting on 908 TKAs performed for 671 patients, met these criteria.

Results:
Mean Knee Society clinical and functional scores increased by 47 and 37 points, respectively. Implant survivorship was reported between 90.6% and 99% during the first decade and between 85% and 96.5% during the second decade of followup. The literature does not direct specific techniques for TKA for young patients.

Conclusions:
TKA provides surgeon-measured clinical and functional improvements with a moderate increase in second-decade implant failures. Improvements in study design and reporting will be beneficial to guide decisions regarding implant selection and surgical technique.

Link to PubMed abstract

 

Ref: Clin Orthop Relat Res. 2010 Sep 3. [Epub ahead of print]

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: What is the evidence for viscosupplementation in the treatment of patients with hip osteoarthritis? Systematic review of the literature
document.publisher: Archives of Orthopaedic and Trauma Surgery
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,OSTEOARTHRITIS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,DRUGS AND PRESCRIBING,TRAUMA,HIP AND PELVIS,HIP OSTEOARTHRITIS,PAIN MANAGEMENT]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Study Design:
Systematic Review.

Objective:
The objective of this review is to asses the efficacy of VS treatment of hip OA osteoarthritis in the current literature.

Methods:
The following databases were searched: Medline (period 1966 to November 2006), Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews (1988 to November 2006), Cochrane Clinical Trial Register (1988 to November 2006), Database of Abstracts on Reviews and Effectiveness, Current Controlled Trials, National Research Register and Embase (January 1988 to November 2006). The search terms [osteoarthritis, hip (joint), viscosupplementation, hyaluronic acid, hyaluronan, sodium hyaluronate and trade names] were applied to identify all studies relating to the use of VS therapy for OA of the hip joint.

Results:
Sixteen articles concerning the efficacy of a total of 509 patients undergoing VS treatment for hip OA were included. Twelve European studies, three Turkish studies and one American study with Levels of Evidence ranging from I to IV evaluated the following products: Hylan G-F 20, Hyalgan, Ostenil, Durolane, Fermatron and Orthovisc. Heterogeneity of included studies did not allow pooled analysis of data.

Conclusion:
Despite the relatively low Level of Evidence of the included studies, VS performed under fluoroscopic or ultrasound guidance seems an effective treatment and may be an alternative treatment of hip OA. Intra-articular injection of (derivatives of) HA into the hip joint appears to be safe and well tolerated. However, VS cannot be recommended as standard therapy in hip OA for wider populations, and therefore the indications remain a highly individualised matter.

Ref: Arch Orthop Trauma Surg. 2008 Aug;128(8):815-23. Epub 2007 Sep 15.

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: What is the role of trauma in the aetiology of OA?
document.publisher: Trauma and Orthopaedics and Musculoskeletal Specialist Libraries
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,MAJOR NON-INFLAMMATORY,OSTEOARTHRITIS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,TRAUMA]]>
document.body:
111-1What is the role of trauma in the aetiology of OA?

Contents>Expert Panel

This editorial was written for the 2007 National Knowledge Week on Osteoarthritis.  The following member of the Expert Panel contributed to this section:   Mr Ben Davis



While osteoarthritis and post-traumatic arthritis may have a common end-point, the pathogenesis of the conditions is initially different. Therefore, to avoid confusion, post-traumatic arthritis (PTA) is the preferred term for degenerative change as a result of trauma.


What do we know about it?

When dealing with patients that have sustained both intra and extra-articular fractures, it is commonplace to inform them of the risks of developing arthritis in the joint, or adjacent joints affected by the injury. This risk is difficult to quantify and varies with the age of the patient, the joint affected, the severity of injury and parameters such as residual limb mal-alignment, stability and congruency. The contribution of trauma to the incidence of “osteoarthritis” is estimated to be around 10%. However, these figures are determined by looking at patients returning for treatment after injury. What remains unknown is the overall incidence of PTA following even the commonest of fractures.


What happens at the time of impact?

Trauma imparts kinetic energy to the body, and in articular and peri-articular fractures this energy is transferred to the joint surface. Macroscopic alteration of the geometry of the joint surface together with disruption of the extra-cellular matrix, and apoptosis of chondrocytes may occur. Injury leads to variable degrees of inflammation with the production of cytokines capable of both cartilage degradation and stimulation. This alters the biochemical composition of the articular cartilage and changes its biomechanical properties making it more susceptible to further injury during loading.  This is exacerbated by the limited healing potential of articular cartilage and its tendency to heal with fibro or “hyaline like” rather than hyaline cartilage. This less robust form of cartilage predisposes to later degenerative change.


What can we do about it?

Steps in the joint surface, and gaps in the articular cartilage decrease joint conformity, while mal-alignment and instability expose the joint surface to abnormal load. Overloading, and unloading are equally detrimental to the health of articular cartilage. In theory, restoring the joint surface and mechanical alignment shuld reduce the incidence of PTA, but what matters most in which location?

Articular steps of greater than 1 or 2 millimetres are often used as blanket indications for surgery. While there is no single “rule” applicable to all injuries, certain trends are evident for particular injuries.

Acetabular fractures have a significantly worse outcome if an anatomical restoration of the joint surface is not achieved. However, in the lateral tibial plateau, up to 10 millimetres of articular depression may be acceptable, without impairing long-term function, providing the overall limb alignment and meniscal function remains acceptable.

For high-energy distal tibial fractures, the quality of reduction of the articular surface may be of secondary importance when compared to the injury to, and management of the soft tissues.

One of the greatest anathemas is the outcome of fractures of the distal radius. While much is published regarding methods of reduction and fixation, together with improved radiographic outcomes, it is clear that little correlation exists between the radiographic appearance of PTA and functional loss. As such, we make the radiograph look better, but we struggle to improve the long-term outcome.


Why should such variation exist?

The time from injury to the development of symptomatic arthritis may be many years and the presence of the cardinal signs of arthritis on radiographs does not mean that a patient will need treatment, or indeed have symptoms. At the time of injury, some degree of at least microscopic irreparable damage is likely to occur to the articular surface. As such, the seed of PTA is sown at the time of impact or injury, and may progress irrespective of our attempts at restoration. Highly congruent weight-bearing joints (such as the hip) will tolerate less articular incongruity than non-weight-bearing or less congruent joints. Factors such as load sharing by the knee menisci serve to protect the damaged articular surface, evidenced by the worse outcome of tibial plateau fractures with associated meniscal damage.


Summary

There is little doubt that trauma leads, in certain circumstances to PTA. At present however, little information exists describing the risks of PTA for even the commonest of fractures. Numerous factors including the joint (and part of the joint) involved, the severity of injury, stability, alignment and perhaps even an individuals’ response to trauma at a molecular level contribute to outcome. Unfortunately, these outcomes can be difficult to measure, in particular noting that radiographic and clinical outcomes do not go hand-in-hand. As such, it would be wise to consider that there are no “rules” that dictate treatment. In an ideal situation, restoration of articular surfaces should be the goal. However, it must be remembered that by achieving this, long-term function may not be improved, and where extensive or complex invasive procedures would be necessary to attain this, the result may be quite the converse.

 
Key Questions

  • What is the incidence of PTA after common fractures?
  • Can early intervention to alter the local inflammatory response to trauma prevent or retard the development of PTA?
  • Which patient factors best predict development of symptomatic PTA after injury?
  • Which injury factors best predict development of symptomatic PTA after injury?
  • For each fracture type and location, what is the best balance between aggressive surgical reconstruction v.s. acceptable residual deformity that will optimise clinical outcome?

 

References

Furman BD, Olson SA, Guilak F. The Development of Post-traumatic Arthritis After Articular Fracture. J Orthop Trauma. 2006. 20 (10) 719-725.  ( Link to PubMed abstract )

Marsh JL, Buckwalter J, Gelberman R et al. Articular fractures: does an anatomic reduction really change the result? J Bone Joint Surg Am 2002; 84A: 1259-1271.   ( Link to full-text - format PDF: Athens password required )

Borelli J. Chondrocyte apoptosis and posttraumatic arthrosis. J Orthop Trauma 2006; 20(10): 726-31.   ( Link to PubMed abstract )

Kim HT, Lo MY, Pillarisetty R. Chondrocyte apoptosis following intra-articular fracture in humans. Osteoarthr Cartil. 2002; 10: 747-749.   ( Link to PubMed abstract )

Goldfarb CA, Rudzki JR, Catalano LW et al. Fifteen-year outcome of displaced intra-articular fractures of the distal radius. J Hand Surg [Am] 2006; 31(4): 633-9.    ( Link to PubMed abstract )  
( Link to full-text - format PDF: Athens password required )

Jaremko JL, Lambert RG, Rowe BH et al. Do radiographic indices of distal radius fracture reduction predict outcomes in older adults receiving conservative treatment? Clin Radiol 2007; 62(1): 65-72.     ( Link to PubMed abstract ) 

Matta J. Fractures of the acetabulum; accuracy of reduction and clinical results in patients managed operatively within three weeks after the injury. J Bone Joint Surg Am 1996; 78: 1632-45.     ( Link to PubMed abstract ) 

Jensen DB, Rude C, Duus B et al. Tibial plateau fractures. A comparison of conservative and surgical treatment. J Bone Joint Surg Br 1990; 72: 49-52.    ( Link to full-text - format PDF )

 

Additional Information


Other Evidence

T. D. Brown, M. J. Rudert, and N. M. Grosland. New methods for assessing cartilage contact stress after articular fracture. Clin Orthop Relat Res (423):52-58, 2004.    ( Link to Pubmed abstract )

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: What is the true evidence for gender-related differences during plant and cut maneuvers? A systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPORTS INJURIES,TRAUMATIC,ANTERIOR CRUCIATE LIGAMENT RUPTURE,TRAUMA,KNEE,LIGAMENT DISORDERS,SOFT TISSUE TRAUMA]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Purpose:
Female athletes have a significantly higher risk of sustaining an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury than male athletes. Biomechanical and neuromuscular factors have been reported as the main cause. The purpose of this review was to critically review results of the published literature on gender differences regarding biomechanical and neuromuscular movement patterns during plant and cutting maneuvers.

Methods:
MEDLINE (1966 to December 2008), EMBASE (1947 to December 2008) and CINAHL (1981 to December 2008) searches were performed. The seven studies meeting the inclusion criteria were analyzed.

Results:
Biomechanical gender differences were of questionable clinical relevance. Quadriceps dominance was not found in women.

Conclusion:
The question raises whether ACL injuries during plant and cutting maneuvers are purely gender related and whether women do have to move like men in order to reduce injury risk? Caution is warranted in making inferences as studies were heterogeneous in terms of subject and study characteristics and had low statistical power as a result of insufficient number of subjects. It is advised that future research moves beyond the isolated gender comparison and that larger sample sizes will be included. This review may aid in improving experiments to draw valid conclusions, in order to direct future ACL injury prevention programs, which might need to be more individualized.

Link to PubMed abstract

 

Ref: Knee Surg Sports Traumatol Arthrosc. 2010 Aug 24. [Epub ahead of print]

]]>

document.body:
Introduction

The purpose of this review is to discuss the research presented on selected topics related to adult knee reconstruction during the year 2008. The articles referenced in this update were selected from both The Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (American Volume) and The Journal of Arthroplasty, as well as select articles from Clinical Orthopaedics and Related Research. All prospective randomized studies related to total knee arthroplasty that were published in these journals in 2008 were reviewed. Other studies were included on the basis of their relevance to the topics that were chosen to be discussed.

 

Ref: J Bone Joint Surg. 2009;91(12):3008-3018

document.title: What's new in sports medicine
document.publisher: Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (American Volume)
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,SPINE,FOOT AND ANKLE,SPORTS INJURIES,CHILDHOOD,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,TRAUMATIC,SURGERY,SPORTS MEDICINE,SHOULDER,ELBOW,HAND AND WRIST,KNEE]]>
document.body:
This overview, which appeared in the American edition of Journal of Bone & Joint Surgery in February 2006, updates on the recent advances made in sports medicine and looks specifically at:

  • knee
  • hip
  • foot and ankle
  • paedicatrics
  • spine
  • wrist and hand
  • shoulder and elbow

The 'Miscellaneous' section covers compartment syndrome, tibial stress fractures, muscle trauma and deep venous thrombosis.

 

Ref:  Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery (American). 2006;88:457-468.

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: Which method of rotator cuff repair leads to the highest rate of structural healing? A systematic review
document.publisher: The American Journal of Sports Medicine
document.topics: <![CDATA[ MUSCULOSKELETAL,CONDITIONS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY,SOFT TISSUE RHEUMATISM,SHOULDER DISORDERS,TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,TRAUMA,SHOULDER,ROTATOR CUFF DISORDERS,ARTHROSCOPY,SOFT TISSUE TRAUMA]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Background:
The purpose of rotator cuff repair is to diminish pain and restore function, and this most predictably occurs when the tendon is demonstrated to heal. Recent improvements in repair methods have led to improved biomechanical performance, but this has not yet been demonstrated to result in higher healing rates. The purpose of our study was to determine whether different repair methods resulted in different rates of recurrent tearing after surgery.

Hypotheses:
We hypothesized that (1) the rotator cuff repair method will not affect retear rate, and (2) the surgical approach will not affect the retear rate for a given repair method.

Study design:
Systematic review of the literature.

Methods:
The literature was systematically searched to find articles reporting imaging study assessment of structural healing rates after rotator cuff repair, with data stratified according to tear size. Retear rates were compared for transosseous (TO), single-row suture anchor (SA), double-row suture anchor (DA), and suture bridge (SB) repair methods, as well as for open (O), miniopen (MO), and arthroscopic (A) approaches.

Results:
Retear rates were available for 1252 repairs collected from 23 studies. Retear rates were significantly lower for double-row repairs when compared with TO or SA for all tears greater than 1 cm and ranged from 7% for tears less than 1 cm to 41% for tears greater than 5 cm, in comparison with retear rates for single-row techniques (TO and SA) of 17% to 69% for tears less than 1 cm and greater than 5 cm, respectively. There was no significant difference in retear rates between TO and SA repair methods or between arthroscopic and nonarthroscopic approaches for any tear size.

Conclusion:
Double-row repair methods lead to significantly lower retear rates when compared with single-row methods for tears greater than 1 cm. Surgical approach has no significant effect on retear rate.

 

Ref: Am J Sports Med. 2010 Apr;38(4):835-41

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: WHO Surgical Safety Checklist – Patient Safety Alert UPDATE
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,NURSING,ANAESTHESIA]]>
document.body:
This alert requires healthcare organisations in England and Wales to implement the WHO Surgical Safety Checklist (adapted for England and Wales) for every patient undergoing a surgical procedure.

The goal is to strengthen the commitment of clinical staff to address safety issues in the surgical setting. This includes:

  • Improving anaesthetic safety practices
  • Ensuring correct site surgery
  • Avoiding surgical site infections
  • Improving communication within the team.

The updates to the alert are:

UPDATE 1: Organisations are required to:

  1. Ensure an executive and a clinical lead are identified in order to implement the surgical safety checklist within the organisation.
  2. Ensure the checklist is completed for every patient undergoing a surgical procedure (including local anaesthesia).
  3. Ensure that the use of the checklist is entered in the clinical notes or electronic record by a registered member of the team, for example: Surgeon/Anaesthetist/Nurse/ODP.

UPDATE 2: Insertion on the checklist (Time Out section) of action for Nurse/ODP.


UPDATE 3: Removal of the Registered Practitioner’s signature from the checklist.

 

For further information about this alert (NPSA/2009/PSA002/U1) and to view the supporting information please go to: http://www.npsa.nhs.uk/nrls/alerts-and-directives/alerts/safer-surgery-alert

]]>

document.name: <![CDATA[ Trauma and Orthopaedics]]>
document.title: Wound closure in flexion versus extension following total knee arthroplasty: a systematic review
document.topics: <![CDATA[ TRAUMA AND ORTHOPAEDICS,DISEASE MANAGEMENT,SURGERY,ARTHROPLASTY,KNEE,WOUND HEALING]]>
document.body:
Abstract

Optimising knee range of motion following total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is important for patient satisfaction, functional outcome and early rehabilitation to promote accelerated discharge. Historically, wound closure following TKA has been performed in extension. It has been suggested that knee position during wound closure may influence range of motion and clinical outcomes following TKA. The purpose of this study was to determine whether TKA wounds should be closed in flexion or extension. An electronic search of MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL and AMED databases was made in addition to a review of unpublished material. All included papers were critically appraised using a modified PEDro (Physiotherapy Evidence Database) critical appraisal tool. Three papers were eligible, assessing 237 TKAs. On analysis, patients with TKA wounds closed in flexion had greater flexion range of motion and required less domiciliary physiotherapy compared to those with wounds closed in full extension. The specific degree of knee flexion used when closing total knee replacement wounds may be an important variable to clinical outcome. However, the present evidence-base is limited in both size and methodological quality.

 

Ref: Acta Orthop Belg. 2010 Jun;76(3):298-306.

]]>
